title: Nicola Sturgeon accused of being 'all over the place' on independence
text:
Nicola Sturgeon accused of being 'all over the place' on independence Nicola Sturgeon's obsession with independence 'damaging Scotland' Auslan Cramb , Scottish Correspondent 8 January 2017 • 10:14pm 
N icola Sturgeon has been accused of being “all over the place” on independence after she warned the Prime Minister she was “not bluffing” about the threat of a new vote on breaking-up Britain. 
The First Minister’s comment came two days after an interview in which she offered to take “indyref2” off the table in the event of a soft Brexit that kept Scotland in the single market. 
Opposition parties said she was trying to use the vote to leave the EU to whip up support for separation and said she was sowing uncertainty and division that was damaging the country. 
Ms Sturgeon urged Theresa May not to “disregard Scotland” and agreed she would seek a new independence vote in the next two-and-a-half years if Scotland was pushed off a “hard Brexit cliff by right-wing Tory Brexiteers”. Watch | Nicola Sturgeon: Scotland 'not bluffing' on second independence referendum 00:19 
S he also said she believed Mrs May still had “no plan” on how the UK would leave the EU, and described talks with the Prime Minister as “frustrating”. 
Ms Sturgeon claimed she was prepared to compromise and needed a UK Government that was prepared to compromise, although her demands for an array of new powers - including control over immigration - have been described as independence by the back door. 
Mrs May later appeared to indicate on Sky News that Britain would leave the single market. When asked about the issue repeatedly, she said she would not try to “keep bits of membership”. 
But Angus Robertson, the SNP’s Westminster leader, claimed the Prime Minister had used “a lot of words to say nothing at all” and offered no clarity on her policy on Brexit. 
Ms Sturgeon told the BBC’s Andrew Marr programme her message to the Prime Minister was “don’t disregard Scotland because it is not acceptable to do so”. Watch | Theresa May not muddled over Brexit plans 02:47 
S he added: “You said during the independence referendum that Scotland was an equal part in the UK, it is now time to prove that. 
“How you respond to the sensible, compromise consensus proposals that the Scottish Government has put forward will tell us much, possibly everything we need to know, about whether Scotland really is an equal partner or whether that is just rhetoric.” 
Told that the view in London was that she was bluffing and would not win another referendum, Ms Sturgeon replied: “They will be making a big mistake if they think that I am in any way bluffing.” 
She added: “I am trying to compromise, you know I lead a party many of whom would want an independence referendum tomorrow. 
“I am trying to act as First Minister to say there is compromise ground. But if we are in a position where I am doing that, but we have a Prime Minster, a UK Government that says no compromise, Scotland just has to shut up and like it or lump it, then the question for Scotland, and it is a much more fundamental question than the EU and Brexit, is are we happy with that? 
“Are we happy to have no voice in the UK, to simply have to accept the direction of travel that an increasingly right-wing UK Government wants to impose upon us?” 
She also said again that a new independence vote could be shelved, within the timescale of Brexit, if the UK as a whole, or Scotland as part of the UK, remained in the single market. 
Her proposals for a soft Brexit would involve keeping the UK in the single market, or exploring ways of keeping Scotland in, while protecting trade across Britain. The second option would require additional powers for Holyrood, including powers over immigration. 
Ruth Davidson, the Scottish Conservative leader, said Ms Sturgeon claimed she was going to take a referendum off the table, only to put it back days later. 
She added: “The SNP are where they’ve always been, trying desperately to use Brexit as a means of whipping up support for independence. 
“The First Minister needs to start acting in the interests of all Scots, not simply playing to her nationalist base. That means ruling out another referendum to give Scottish business the certainty it needs.” 
Willie Rennie, Scottish Lib Dem leader, added: “The First Minister is all over the place on independence. One minute she backs off, the next she threatens to break up the UK.” Kezia Dugdale, the Scottish Labour leader, said Ms Sturgeon was sowing division when Scotland needed to pull together. 
A spokesman for the UK Government reiterated its position that it was committed to a deal “that works for all parts of the UK, including Scotland”. Follow Telegraph News
